title: Lady Anne Berry, plantswoman who built Rosemoor in Devon into one of Britain’s finest public gardens – obituary
text:
Lady Anne Berry, who has died aged 99, spent nearly 30 years creating one of Britain’s best-known public gardens, Rosemoor in Devon, before donating it to the Royal Horticultural Society and emigrating to New Zealand, where she and her second husband developed an extensive arboretum.

A descendant of Robert Walpole, 1st Earl of Orford, the 18th century Whig politician who became Britain’s longest-serving prime minister, she was three when her father, the 5th earl, bought Rosemoor, a Regency house, to use as a fishing lodge. The River Torridge, which runs alongside the property, was made famous by Henry Williamson in his novel Tarka the Otter (1927).
